metadata.synopsis: Brian Kessler (David Duchovny) is a writer, and his girlfriend, Carrie Laughlin (Michelle Forbes), is a photographer. They're working on a book about serial killers, and planning a trip across the country to document the sites of famous serial murders. To cut costs, they set up a ride-share with strangers, Early Grayce (Brad Pitt) and his girlfriend, Adele Corners (Juliette Lewis). But what they don't know is that Early is a violent sociopath in the middle of his own serial killing spree.

reviews: Sena has a nifty knack for playing out major twists in a minor key.

Pitt and Lewis have made an unfortunate choice for their first big-screen collaboration. In fact, the flashes of acting brilliance that they show in this messy, often-pretentious production are its only real points of interest.
It is pulpy trash masquerading as an art film, ultimately failing to be either.
An uneven mess of a vehicle for its stars, one that did no favors for anyone starring, including Pitt.
What makes Kalifornia intriguing is the manner in which these characters all relate to one another. Where the film suffers is in its obliviousness toward its own obviousness.
Parts of it seem intent on being a thriller, while others are played as though the story is a dark comedy. Consequently, you aren't always sure whether to laugh or tense up.
If you hop aboard this sick, unjoyful ride, you'd better bail out early. Unsafe at any speed, this dramatic vehicle goes up in flames.
The movie is a road trip that takes a bad turn to hell. Check it out.

Brad Pitt's performance is crucial, and he rips into the character with a frightening sense of unhinged egomania, violently subverting the Redford-lite pretty-boy image with which so many wanted to associate him

The movie begins extremely well before escalating into the inevitable Straw Dogs confrontation, when the sensitive-intellectual man discovers, just like Dustin Hoffman, that when push comes to shove, we're all brutes and animals.
An Absolutely riveting movie...Pitt is outstanding
A gritty, haunting voyeur's peek into the human condition.
